conversation.content: [bitter] I saw them practicing, um, the nerve strikes I taught you, [shaky voice], using them for, well, combat drills with, [quietly], automatic weapons and ambush tactics.
[defensive] So, umm, what?
[frustrated] You promised me when you joined this dojo that you would, [trembling], honor our code of using martial arts only for self-defense, never for, [loudly], aggression or warfare.

My people are dying every day, uh, in villages where self-defense means, [passionately], nothing against tanks and air strikes, so yeah, I mean, I adapted what you taught me to, [angry], save lives. [sigh]

[confused] How can you stand there and tell me that teaching, [hesitantly], guerrilla fighters to kill more efficiently is somehow, [very quietly], saving lives when violence only breeds more, [whispering], violence?

[stern] Your peaceful philosophy works great in your, [sarcastic], comfortable suburban dojo where the biggest threat is someone forgetting to, [mocking], bow properly, but my reality involves watching children starve under blockades. [groan]

You think I don't, um, understand suffering because I choose, [empathetically], peace over violence, but, well, every technique I teach comes from centuries of, [slowly], warriors who learned that true strength means knowing when not to fight.

[apologetic] Look, I mean, I never wanted to betray your trust but, umm, when they asked me to train them, [regretful], I couldn't say no knowing that proper technique might mean, [crying while speaking], the difference between their families living or, well, dying in the next raid.

[warm] I taught you those techniques because I saw someone who could, [sincerely], carry forward our tradition with honor, not weaponize it for, [disappointed], political warfare regardless of how justified you think the cause might be.
[exhausted] Political warfare is what you call it when you're, [angrily], watching from the outside. [laugh]

[very meekly] Maybe I've been naive, umm, thinking that martial arts could remain pure in, well, an impure world, but, [trailing off], watching you twist everything I taught you still breaks my heart. [sniffle]
[anxious] The heart-breaking part is that you taught me discipline gives us choices, [pause], but you never considered that sometimes all the choices are terrible. [cough]

[sad] So what happens now, um, when every strike you taught them carries my teachings but, [whispering loudly], none of my philosophy, and, uhh, blood spills using forms I spent decades perfecting for, [monotone], peace? [gasp softly]
[confident] Well, what happens is that, um, maybe thirty kids survive ambushes they wouldn't have survived otherwise because, [speeding up], they know how to move silently and strike precisely.
[upset] I suppose this is goodbye then, because I cannot continue teaching someone who sees my life's work as just, [coldly], another weapon in their arsenal.

[pleading] Please don't make this about choosing sides when, umm, I'm just trying to give my people a fighting chance using, [desperately], whatever tools I can find, including the beautiful, [tearfully], deadly art you taught me so well. [cry]
[formal] Return your belt to the shrine before you leave, as you no longer represent, [firmly], this dojo or its values.
[resigned] I'll return the belt but not the knowledge, which will, [defiantly], live on in every fighter I train, transformed into something you'd hate but they'll, [proudly], call survival.

Then I suppose, well, we both failed—me as your teacher for not, [melancholic], seeing who you really were, and you as my student for, err, becoming everything our art stands, [bitterly], against. [long pause]

[sympathetic] Maybe one day when the fighting stops, you'll understand that sometimes betraying, [gently], a principle is the only way to honor the people that principle was meant to, [hopeful], protect in the first place. [deep breath]
